statement.text: Acute Mesenteric Ischemia (AMI) is a life-threatening surgical emergency characterized by sudden interruption of intestinal blood flow, most commonly due to arterial embolism or thrombosis to the superior mesenteric artery, requiring urgent diagnosis and intervention to prevent bowel necrosis.
statement.formal: AMI: Sudden mesenteric blood flow interruption → Intestinal hypoxia → Progressive ischemic cascade → Transmural necrosis (6-12 hours) → Perforation/Sepsis → Multi-organ failure/Death

explanation.intuition: Acute mesenteric ischemia is the intestinal equivalent of a heart attack or stroke - a sudden blockage of blood flow to a vital organ with a very narrow time window for intervention. Unlike a limb, which can tolerate hours of ischemia, the intestine begins irreversible damage within 6 hours.
explanation.key_insight: The phrase 'pain out of proportion to examination' captures the diagnostic challenge: patients present with severe, often diffuse abdominal pain, but physical examination is deceptively benign until peritonitis develops. By the time peritoneal signs appear, bowel necrosis has already occurred.
explanation.technical_details: The ischemic cascade involves: (1) mucosal hypoxia within minutes, (2) villous injury and barrier breakdown within 1-2 hours, (3) bacterial translocation and reperfusion injury, (4) transmural necrosis by 6-12 hours, (5) perforation and peritonitis. The SMA is most commonly affected due to its acute angle of origin from the aorta, making it a preferred landing site for emboli.

definitions_glossary.AMI: Acute Mesenteric Ischemia - sudden intestinal blood flow interruption
definitions_glossary.SMA: Superior Mesenteric Artery - primary blood supply to small bowel and right colon
definitions_glossary.embolism: Blood clot or debris traveling from a proximal source to lodge distally
definitions_glossary.thrombosis: In-situ clot formation on an existing atherosclerotic lesion
definitions_glossary.NOMI: Non-occlusive Mesenteric Ischemia - ischemia without mechanical obstruction
definitions_glossary.MVT: Mesenteric Venous Thrombosis - clot in mesenteric veins
definitions_glossary.second_look_laparotomy: Planned re-exploration to assess bowel viability after revascularization

arterial_embolism.source: Cardiac (atrial fibrillation, recent MI, valvular disease)
arterial_embolism.location: Typically lodges 3-10 cm distal to SMA origin (past middle colic artery)
characteristics: Proximal jejunum and colon often spared
arterial_embolism.prognosis: Better than thrombosis if promptly treated

arterial_thrombosis.source: In-situ thrombosis on existing atherosclerotic plaque
characteristics: May have history of postprandial pain (food fear)
arterial_thrombosis.prognosis: Worse than embolism due to more extensive disease

characteristics: Often occurs in critically ill ICU patients

venous_thrombosis.source: Hypercoagulable states, portal hypertension, abdominal inflammation
venous_thrombosis.location: Superior mesenteric vein, may extend to portal vein
venous_thrombosis.prognosis: Better than arterial if diagnosed early (20-50% mortality)

classic_presentation.pain: Severe, periumbilical or diffuse, out of proportion to examination

related.relationship: AF is the most common source of mesenteric emboli

sources.citation: Björck M, et al. ESVS Guidelines on Management of Acute Mesenteric Ischemia. Eur J Vasc Endovasc Surg. 2017
Bala M, et al. Acute mesenteric ischemia: guidelines of WSES. World J Emerg Surg. 2017;12:38

learning_objectives: Define AMI and distinguish from chronic mesenteric ischemia
Compare and contrast the four etiologic categories
Understand the temporal progression of intestinal ischemia
clinical_pearls: Think AMI in any patient with sudden severe abdominal pain and atrial fibrillation
The 'pain-examination gap' (severe pain, benign exam) is pathognomonic early
By the time peritoneal signs develop, you are already behind
NOMI is the stealth killer - look for it in your ICU patients on pressors
